p.s: Description of Actinomadura yumaensis sp. nov.
Actinomadura yumaensis (yú ma.en.sis. Lat. derivative of Yuma County, Ariz., the source of the soil sample from which the type strain was isolated)
Actinomadura yumaensis forms branching substrate hyphae and, on some media, produces short, loosely coiled (usually one turn) chains of smooth-surfaced spores.
The spore chains are borne on branched, almost verticillate sporophores and average 20 spores in length.
The spores are ovoid and measure 0.6 to 0.8 by 1.0 to 1.4 μm.
Substrate mycelium is generally of yellow shades, ranging from pale yellow to dark yellowish brown.
Yellow to dark green soluble pigments are produced on many media.
The aerial mycelium is white to yellowish white, becoming gray
The physiological properties of this species are summarized in Tables 2 and 3.
The optimum temperature for growth is 37°C.
The type strain is strain NRRL 12515 (= LL-C23024).
